results.title: Pedal power
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A new look at the self-propelled bicycle, the most effective known way of translating energy into motion. Traces the development of the bicycle and examines the bicycle’s possible role in the modern transport scene in the light of the present world fuel crisis.

results.title: Dawn of the clone age
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Deborah Cadbury
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Dolly the sheep’s birth on 23 February 1997 became world news for Dolly was to be the first successful cloning of a sheep. The next step surely would be the cloning of humans! This interesting and informative documentary tells the story behind this most amazing feat in biological research and of the team who were responsible in bringing it about. The program also discusses the bioethics and concerns raised by many in the scientific and academic world about cloning and genetic engineering, particularly in the cloned embryo area. Includes interviews with some of “Dolly’s” creators, namely Dr Ian Wilmut, Dr Henry Griffin, Dr John Clark and Dr Keith Campbell (all from the Roslin Institute) and uses microphotography and computer animation to illustrate the intricacies involved in the research and techniques of genetic engineering and embryology. Poses the question about the future and the “brave new world” of cloning - will it be used in the treatment of diseases such as cystic fibrosis or haemophilia or, as feared by many, in the cloning of super humans? Narrated by Hugh Quarshie.

results.title: How do you read?
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Stephen Rose and Harris Watts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Being unable to read is a personal disaster. Learning to read at an early age is very important. This film demonstrates various modern techniques and devices used to increase reading speed, and it shows that the speed of reading and the rate of comprehension are related to the material being studied.

results.title: Outbreak: the microbe masters the mould
results.creator_credit: Oliver Morse, David Dugan and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Golden Staph is an organism which has developed various strains that are resistant to most of the antibiotics used today. This documentary looks at the very serious problems that resulted from an outbreak of this virulent organism at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, in 1981, and the stringent methods which were used to control the spread of infection.

results.title: The Lost waters of the Nile
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, KRO-TV Hilversum and Alec Nisbett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Report on the issues surrounding the construction of the Jonglei Canal, a massive engineering project intended to bypass an enormous area of marshland formed by the waters of the White Nile. Considers in particular the effects on the Dinka people who inhabit the area and the difficulties facing the builders of the canal.

results.title: Migraine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A look at some of the recent research work by scientists in Britain who are attempting to understand and provide treatment for people who suffer from blinding headaches, known as migraines. Shows the problems these sufferers can face in their work and social life.

results.title: A Lesson for teacher (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style

results.title: Let the therapy fit the crime
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Brian Gibson and Michael Andrews
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
There is a high proportion of persistent offenders in Britain’s gaols. There are two schools of thought concerning the reasons for criminality. Behaviouralists consider that personality is determined by heredity as well as by environment, while psychoanalysts maintain that a criminal’s aggressive behaviour arises out of internal conflict resulting from traumatic experiences in early life. Both schools of thought believe that remedial treatment and not punishment is the only way to help people.
